Our speculation, to be tenable, should be supported by the proportion of basic references in all experimental research, regardless of outlet. The proportion for letters journals alluded to above, however, exceeds 25 per cent. <div class="refDocTitle fontMedium">
<a class="outwardLink" title="Abstract + Refs(opens in a new window)" href="https://www-scopus-com.sire.ub.edu/record/display.uri?eid=2-s2.0-0009156801&amp;origin=reflist&amp;sort=plf-f&amp;src=s&amp;sid=6ce362d4735ed6185ffbf73a096eb9ae&amp;sot=b&amp;sdt=b&amp;sl=88&amp;s=SRCTITLE%28the+AND+evaluation+AND+of+AND+research+AND+by+AND+scientometric+AND+indicators%29">Bibliographical statistics as a guide to growth points in science</a>
		<a class="outwardLink" title="UB.Consulta'l(opens in a new window)" href="https://www-scopus-com.sire.ub.edu/redirect/linking.uri?targetURL=https%3a%2f%2fcercabib.ub.edu%2fopenurl%2f34CSUC_UB%2f34CSUC_UB%3aVU1%3f%3fsid%3dElsevier%3aScopus%26_service_type%3dgetFullTxt%26issn%3d14603659%26isbn%3d%26volume%3d1%26issue%3d1%26spage%3d95%26epage%3d99%26pages%3d95-99%26artnum%3d%26date%3d1971%26id%3ddoi%3a10.1177%252f030631277100100107%26title%3dSocial%2bStudies%2bof%2bScience%26atitle%3dBibliographical%2bstatistics%2bas%2ba%2bguide%2bto%2bgrowth%2bpoints%2bin%2bscience%26aufirst%3dA.J.%26auinit%3dA.J.%26auinit1%3dA%26aulast%3dMeadows&amp;locationID=3&amp;categoryID=6&amp;eid=2-s2.0-0009156801&amp;issn=14603659&amp;linkType=TemplateLinking&amp;year=1971&amp;zone=outwardlinks&amp;origin=reflist&amp;dig=8ef684f40c24945edb53d823aa63c8db" target="_blank"></a>
</div>
<br>(1971)&nbsp;<em>Social Studies of Science</em>,&nbsp;1&nbsp;(1),&nbsp;pp. 95-99.&nbsp;<a href="https://www-scopus-com.sire.ub.edu/search/submit/citedby.uri?eid=2-s2.0-0009156801&amp;src=s&amp;origin=reflist&amp;refstat=core" title="View the 54 publications that cite this one" class="">Cited 54 times</a>.<br>doi: 10.1177/030631277100100107<br>

<div class="checkbox">
<input type="checkbox" aria-label="" name="selectedEIDs" id="reference-8" onclick="toggleSelectAllChkBox(this);" value="2-s2.0-84965579050">
<label for="reference-8" class="checkbox-label">
8
</label>
</div>
</th>
<td class="refCont">
<div class="refAuthorTitle"><em>Science Citation Index</em>.&nbsp;<a href="https://www-scopus-com.sire.ub.edu/search/submit/citedby.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84965579050&amp;src=s&amp;origin=reflist&amp;refstat=dummy" title="View the 28 publications that cite this one" class="">Cited 28 times</a>.<br>g In keeping with our earlier caveats and concern for validating data, a high priority strategy for further experimentation should be the following: (1) select a set of papers in a specialty; (2) consult the SCI and compile a distribution of citation counts for these papers; (3) sample from the various segments of this distribution (e.g. high, medium, and low cited); (4) select another sample of citing papers within each stratum (5) classify each cited paper according to the context in which it is referenced; (6) observe whether the distribution of reference types conforms to the distribution of citations (e.g. highly cited papers are predominantly affirmative-essential); (7) control for the form and content of the citing and cited articles and for characteristics of the authors involved. Such an experiment would reverse the approach taken in the last part of this paper - namely, subjecting the reference typology to validation by SCI counts<br></div>
<div class="featuresRow marginTop1">
<ul id="outwardLinkSection" class="list-inline">
<li class="last">&nbsp;</li>
</ul>
</div>
